free_text.Forme d'enseignement: After ex-cathedra introduction sessions, detailing the pathophysiology of common metabolic diseases and selected infectious diseases, the teaching proceeds with weekly sessions of office hours and group work in close collaboration with the teachers
free_text.Contenu: [li] General principles of drug development [target-based versus whole cell-based screens, target identification, target validation, screening, hit to lead optimization, rational drug design, process research (optimization of the chemical synthesis for the pilot plant and factory), efficacy, toxicity / safety, preclinical & clinical development, ,..] [br/][li] Use of animal models and human genetics in drug discovery[br/][li] The business environment [markets, patients/consumers, competitors][br/][li] Project management [sponsors, stake-holders and their expectations, checkpoints, milestones, execution][br/][li] Commercialization [business plan, regulatory, product launch, Intellectual property][br/][li] Pathophysiology and therapeutic strategies for disorders of energy balance [fasting-feeding cycles, nutrition, Perception Physiology, hormonal control of energy homeostasis, obesity, anorexia, prevention and treatments][br/][li] Pathophysiology and therapeutic strategies for cardio-metabolic diseases [type1-2 diabetes, atherosclerotic heart disease, lipid homeostasis, chronic inflammation, diagnosis, pathogenesis, prevention and treatment][br/][li] Pathophysiology and therapeutic strategies for HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis emphasizing the importance of combination therapy and the dangers of drug-drug interactions.[br/][li] Case studies
free_text.Forme du contrôle: [b] Continuous - during the semester[/b][br/]- Written Project[br/]- Oral defense of the project
free_text.Objectifs d'apprentissage: The goal of this course is to instruct the student how fundamental scientific knowledge, acquired through the study of basic disciplines, including biochemistry, genetics, pharmacology, physiology, genomics, cell and molecular biology can be applied for drug discovery and development in a commercial context. We will illustrate how basic scientific knowledge translates into medical advances and serves as the steppingstone, to identify and validate new disease targets, to develop drugs, and to improve diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of common diseases. We will show these principles by disease-driven examples, which will focus on common diseases, such as obesity, diabetes, and atherosclerotic heart disease, and infectious diseases such as HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis. Selected speakers with industry experience may participate in teaching
